issue.title: [Feature] Support for new Ring Intercom device
issue.body:
Ring released a new device: the [Ring Intercom](https://en-uk.ring.com/products/intercom)

It' wired up to the building's intercom system and mainly supports these features:
- open the door
- notify when the door bell is pressed
- use the intercom's audio in a voice call

I bought one and tried to integrate it into my Home Assistant via the [`ring` integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/ring) ([`ring` source code](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/tree/dev/homeassistant/components/ring)), which uses this python package under the hood.

Unfortunately the Ring Intercom does not appear in the list of devices. As it's the only Ring device I own, I can't check whether it's working in general, but from the logs the authentication appears to be successful.

My theory is that the device is not showing up, because this package doesn't yet recognize this type of device.

issue.title: Unfound exports `LinkParams` and `UILinkParams` under Embroider
issue.body:
I assume this is because these exports are actually TS interfaces and should be exported using `export type`?

```
WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'LinkParams' (reexported as 'LinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85

WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'UILinkParams' (reexported as 'UILinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85
```

pull_request.title: Fix exporting `LinkParams` and `UILinkParams` types
pull_request.body: Closes #717.

Perfect, thank you!

issue.title: [Bug] 2.3.2 broke `observes` modifier

comment.body: I can confirm the `{ on: 'init' }` bug as well. Fortunately we were only using this in a single service, which we fixed by calling `.perform()` in the `init()` hook.

@chriskrycho

- Should I keep pointing at my fork here?
- Or should we switch to a different tool like [API Extractor](https://api-extractor.com/) first? If so, ...
  - Which tool would prefer?
  - Should this be split out into an extra PR that is merged before this one?
- Or do you have a completely different solution to this in mind?

commits.message:
fix(types): allow `exactOptionalPropertyTypes` (#1715)

* enable exactOptionalPropertyTypes

* update RelativeTimeFormatOptions to work with exactOptionalPropertyTypes

* style: auto-format with `prettier`

Co-authored-by: Jan Buschtöns <jan@buschtoens.me>

pull_request.title: fix(types): allow `exactOptionalPropertyTypes`
pull_request.body:
v5.x is not currently compatible with apps that have [`exactOptionalPropertyTypes`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig#exactOptionalPropertyTypes) enabled. This turns that option on here and updates the types of `RelativeTimeFormatOptions` to be compatible.

The reason why this is required is that the `& keyof KnownOptions` restriction here:
https://github.com/ember-intl/ember-intl/blob/daad6f592fdd7e52f01df058e43c0a4f847149f6/addon/-private/formatters/-base.ts#L61
forces the return type to include `| undefined` for each option key.

@ijlee2 @buschtoens

repo.description: Localization library for any Ember Application or Addon

issue.title: Unfound exports `LinkParams` and `UILinkParams` under Embroider
issue.body:
I assume this is because these exports are actually TS interfaces and should be exported using `export type`?

```
WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'LinkParams' (reexported as 'LinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85

WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'UILinkParams' (reexported as 'UILinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85
```

comment.body: Good catch! Yes, I think that's the cause.

Yep! I've touched on that in my most recent comment in the RFC: https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210790596

I also suggested not using the `owner`, but the invoking template context. I'd be very interested in your opinion on that.

pull_request.title: feat: bind `this` context to owner
pull_request.body: This PR binds `this` in functions invoked as a helper to the owner. I've suggested this behavior in https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210588525 and wanted to show a very rudimentary PoC.

issue.title: Default Helper Manager

labels.name: T-framework
labels.description: RFCs that impact the ember.js library

issue.body: [Rendered](https://github.com/NullVoxPopuli/rfcs/blob/helper-default-manager/text/0756-helper-default-manager.md)

comment.body:
@chriskrycho Thank you for the super-swift reply! ⚡

I am 💯 on-board with what you're saying about retaining normal JS binding rules for method invocations, i.e. `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` ≡ `foo.bar("baz")`.

(And I'm very interested in helping! In general, I would like to familiarize myself more with the Glimmer internals. So far I only ever really ventured in there, when fixing bugs.)

Coming back to the owner as `this` binding idea: I might have expressed myself unclearly. I did not mean that an invocation like `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` should be bound to the owner instead of `foo`, though this is an interesting aspect, that I didn't explicitly consider before.

As a matter of fact "bind" might be the wrong term to use. The function / method itself should not be bound to the owner as `fn.bind(owner)` would. Instead the `owner` should be set as the `this` context, when the function is invoked, e.g. `fn.call(owner, ...args)`.

IMO this can co-exist with `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` being "bound" to `foo`, when only simple identifiers (`{{{bar "baz"}}`) receive `owner` as `this`. Key paths would always use the second-to-last segment, like JS (`{{foo.bar.qux "baz"}}` → `foo.bar.qux('baz')`). In the same way, if you "chop off" a method and only pass that reference, then it shouldn't be bound to its host object any more, just like in JS.

```hbs
{{foo.bar "baz"}} → bound to `foo`

{{#let foo.bar as |bar|}}
  {{bar "baz"}} → bound to owner
{{/let}}
```

I've implemented a quick PoC for the polyfill. Of course it doesn't yet have any special handling for key paths.
https://github.com/ember-polyfills/ember-functions-as-helper-polyfill/pull/132

You're mention of key paths got me thinking though: Maybe we shouldn't use the owner for `this`, but the actual _template context_, i.e. the backing component class instance. The `owner` could be obtained from there.

I can imagine scenarios, where convenient access to the template context without explicitly requiring the user to pass `this` as extra argument is useful. This also means that helper functions would _always_ use `getOwner(this)` in order to get the owner, assuming that if they're invoked via a host object (`{{foo.bar "baz"}}`), that host object does have an associated owner.

pull_request.title: feat: bind `this` context to owner
pull_request.body: This PR binds `this` in functions invoked as a helper to the owner. I've suggested this behavior in https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210588525 and wanted to show a very rudimentary PoC.

repo.name: ember-functions-as-helper-polyfill
repo.description: Implementation of RFC 756, Default Helper Manager

issue.title: [Feature] Support for new Ring Intercom device
issue.body:
Ring released a new device: the [Ring Intercom](https://en-uk.ring.com/products/intercom)

It' wired up to the building's intercom system and mainly supports these features:
- open the door
- notify when the door bell is pressed
- use the intercom's audio in a voice call

I bought one and tried to integrate it into my Home Assistant via the [`ring` integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/ring) ([`ring` source code](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/tree/dev/homeassistant/components/ring)), which uses this python package under the hood.

Unfortunately the Ring Intercom does not appear in the list of devices. As it's the only Ring device I own, I can't check whether it's working in general, but from the logs the authentication appears to be successful.

My theory is that the device is not showing up, because this package doesn't yet recognize this type of device.

commits.message:
fix(types): allow `exactOptionalPropertyTypes` (#1715)

* enable exactOptionalPropertyTypes

* update RelativeTimeFormatOptions to work with exactOptionalPropertyTypes

* style: auto-format with `prettier`

Co-authored-by: Jan Buschtöns <jan@buschtoens.me>

pull_request.title: fix(types): allow `exactOptionalPropertyTypes`
pull_request.body:
v5.x is not currently compatible with apps that have [`exactOptionalPropertyTypes`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig#exactOptionalPropertyTypes) enabled. This turns that option on here and updates the types of `RelativeTimeFormatOptions` to be compatible.

The reason why this is required is that the `& keyof KnownOptions` restriction here:
https://github.com/ember-intl/ember-intl/blob/daad6f592fdd7e52f01df058e43c0a4f847149f6/addon/-private/formatters/-base.ts#L61
forces the return type to include `| undefined` for each option key.

@ijlee2 @buschtoens

issue.title: Unfound exports `LinkParams` and `UILinkParams` under Embroider
issue.body:
I assume this is because these exports are actually TS interfaces and should be exported using `export type`?

```
WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'LinkParams' (reexported as 'LinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85

WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'UILinkParams' (reexported as 'UILinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85
```

comment.body: Good catch! Yes, I think that's the cause.

Yep! I've touched on that in my most recent comment in the RFC: https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210790596

I also suggested not using the `owner`, but the invoking template context. I'd be very interested in your opinion on that.

pull_request.title: feat: bind `this` context to owner
pull_request.body: This PR binds `this` in functions invoked as a helper to the owner. I've suggested this behavior in https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210588525 and wanted to show a very rudimentary PoC.

issue.title: Default Helper Manager

labels.name: T-framework
labels.description: RFCs that impact the ember.js library

issue.body: [Rendered](https://github.com/NullVoxPopuli/rfcs/blob/helper-default-manager/text/0756-helper-default-manager.md)

comment.body:
@chriskrycho Thank you for the super-swift reply! ⚡

I am 💯 on-board with what you're saying about retaining normal JS binding rules for method invocations, i.e. `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` ≡ `foo.bar("baz")`.

(And I'm very interested in helping! In general, I would like to familiarize myself more with the Glimmer internals. So far I only ever really ventured in there, when fixing bugs.)

Coming back to the owner as `this` binding idea: I might have expressed myself unclearly. I did not mean that an invocation like `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` should be bound to the owner instead of `foo`, though this is an interesting aspect, that I didn't explicitly consider before.

As a matter of fact "bind" might be the wrong term to use. The function / method itself should not be bound to the owner as `fn.bind(owner)` would. Instead the `owner` should be set as the `this` context, when the function is invoked, e.g. `fn.call(owner, ...args)`.

IMO this can co-exist with `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` being "bound" to `foo`, when only simple identifiers (`{{{bar "baz"}}`) receive `owner` as `this`. Key paths would always use the second-to-last segment, like JS (`{{foo.bar.qux "baz"}}` → `foo.bar.qux('baz')`). In the same way, if you "chop off" a method and only pass that reference, then it shouldn't be bound to its host object any more, just like in JS.

```hbs
{{foo.bar "baz"}} → bound to `foo`

{{#let foo.bar as |bar|}}
  {{bar "baz"}} → bound to owner
{{/let}}
```

I've implemented a quick PoC for the polyfill. Of course it doesn't yet have any special handling for key paths.
https://github.com/ember-polyfills/ember-functions-as-helper-polyfill/pull/132

You're mention of key paths got me thinking though: Maybe we shouldn't use the owner for `this`, but the actual _template context_, i.e. the backing component class instance. The `owner` could be obtained from there.

I can imagine scenarios, where convenient access to the template context without explicitly requiring the user to pass `this` as extra argument is useful. This also means that helper functions would _always_ use `getOwner(this)` in order to get the owner, assuming that if they're invoked via a host object (`{{foo.bar "baz"}}`), that host object does have an associated owner.

pull_request.title: feat: bind `this` context to owner
pull_request.body: This PR binds `this` in functions invoked as a helper to the owner. I've suggested this behavior in https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/756#issuecomment-1210588525 and wanted to show a very rudimentary PoC.

issue.title: [Feature] Support for new Ring Intercom device
issue.body:
Ring released a new device: the [Ring Intercom](https://en-uk.ring.com/products/intercom)

It' wired up to the building's intercom system and mainly supports these features:
- open the door
- notify when the door bell is pressed
- use the intercom's audio in a voice call

I bought one and tried to integrate it into my Home Assistant via the [`ring` integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/ring) ([`ring` source code](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/tree/dev/homeassistant/components/ring)), which uses this python package under the hood.

Unfortunately the Ring Intercom does not appear in the list of devices. As it's the only Ring device I own, I can't check whether it's working in general, but from the logs the authentication appears to be successful.

My theory is that the device is not showing up, because this package doesn't yet recognize this type of device.

 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85

WARNING in ./node_modules/ember-link/index.js 1:0-75
export 'UILinkParams' (reexported as 'UILinkParams') was not found in './link' (possible exports: UILink, default, isQueryParams)
 @ ./components/dropdown/actions/link/index.js 13:0-34 16:117-121
 @ ./tests/integration/components/dropdown/actions/link-test.js 5:0-74 7:9-11
 @ ./assets/test.js 32:13-85
```

issue.title: [Bug] 2.3.2 broke `observes` modifier

comment.body: I can confirm the `{ on: 'init' }` bug as well. Fortunately we were only using this in a single service, which we fixed by calling `.perform()` in the `init()` hook.

@chriskrycho

- Should I keep pointing at my fork here?
- Or should we switch to a different tool like [API Extractor](https://api-extractor.com/) first? If so, ...
  - Which tool would prefer?
  - Should this be split out into an extra PR that is merged before this one?
- Or do you have a completely different solution to this in mind?

I am 💯 on-board with what you're saying about retaining normal JS binding rules for method invocations, i.e. `{{foo.bar "baz"}}` ≡ `foo.bar("baz")`.
